dialogue.sentence:
James: I have a question about citing Internet sources in our research paper.
Vince: Well, it depends on the source.
James: ----
Vince: Of course not. We're writing an academic paper and all the information should be reliable.
options: I see. Why don't we go to the computer lab and check the database?
So are you saying that we should consult our advisors first?
The Internet has the necessary information. It isn't worth going to the library, is it?
What do you mean by that? Can't we cite every source we find online?
I didn't get your point. Would you please be more specific?

dialogue.sentence:
Robert: Why is Galileo considered to be so important?
Jessica: He invented the astronomical telescope and suggested a sun-centred Solar System.
Jessica: ----
Robert: It's really surprising that you're questioning it. His studies started everything about the Universe!
options: Yes, I also learnt that he used improved telescopes to identify the moons of Jupiter.
Doesn't everybody know that his obsession with measurable experiments marked him as one of the founders of modern science?
He did but it's unfortunate that his conflict with the Church led to the censorship of his publications.
I know all about this, but I just can't understand why so many popular writers still mention him in their works.
Maybe you can check it online before you believe what people say about him.

dialogue.sentence:
Journalist: Could you tell us about the food industries threatened by antibiotic resistance?
Researcher: Certainly.
Journalist: ----
Researcher: For example, if you buy a farmed salmon today, chances are it will have eaten a greater weight of antibiotics during its life than its own body weight.
options: We know that farmers rely heavily on antibiotics. What is the reason behind their practices?
What can health scientists and clinicians do to sort out the problem?
Can you tell us how antimicrobial resistance affects food?
Do you think food industries could collapse if resistance spreads?
What else does the report warn us about?

dialogue.sentence:
Eda: I haven't seen you on social media for a long time. What's going on?
Çiğdem: ----
Eda: You've done the right thing! Experts say browsing social media sites leads to depression as it triggers a feeling of envy among users.
Çiğdem: That could be true, as well. But my reason is being too busy to use it these days, not because I'm jealous of others.
options: I'm afraid I've forgotten my password, so I can't log in these days.
Well, seeing how people are satisfied with their lives gets on my nerves.
I believe it's a waste of time and I do nothing but follow the lives of people around me.
I didn't expect you'd notice my absence, but don't worry I'll be back very soon.
I've closed my account as I've got much more important stuff to do.

dialogue.sentence:
Mert: I've got this pain in my leg from running.
Fatma: ----
Mert: No, I've been running in the mornings for the last three months, I haven't taken a break.
options: Do you stop for water breaks when you're running?
Do you always suffer pain after running?
Do you usually run in the evenings?
Was it your first time running for a while?
Do you think it would help staying healthy?

dialogue.sentence:
Kevin: What do you think was David Beckham's greatest achievement?
Richard: ----
Kevin: Actually, no. He says his greatest achievement has been always putting his family first.
options: Let me guess! He must've said something about his career playing for several well-known clubs.
How would I know? I've never met a celebrity in my life!
That's easy. Celebrities always say they put their loved ones and friends first.
That's a really tricky question. He's had such a successful career that anything could be considered great!
In my opinion, the real achievement is what you do for others in your daily life.

dialogue.sentence:
Interviewer: How safe is our personal information without any apps?
Tech Expert: Not safe at all. Even a simple Wifi software can reveal a lot.
Interviewer: ----
Tech Expert: By using this software, I can see which Wifi networks you've connected to before, I can predict your financial status, and I can also figure out where you live and work.
options: What do you think is safe about this software?
What kind of information could you possibly learn through Wifi connection?
How can I protect my personal information from this type of software?
What would be the best way to detect such threats?
Are there any other ways to get information about people in addition to Wifi connection?

dialogue.sentence:
Jane: I've read that there could be another planet in our Solar System.
Ronald: If so, it must be quite distant from the Sun.
Jane: ----
Ronald: Oh, don't worry. If one's out there, they'll find it! Science has been improving faster than we may think.
options: Astronomers are going to start analysing the movements of objects in the Solar System soon.
Do you think that scientists will ever be able to find another one?
I hope people will be able to travel across the universe in the future.
Will people ever believe that there could be life on other planets?
What if it was not that far from the Sun or our planet?

dialogue.sentence:
Teacher: Which book by Arthur Conan Doyle have you read recently?
Student: The Return of Sherlock Holmes.
Teacher: ----
Student: Because it's the collected short-story adventures published after the Great Detective's return from the dead.
options: Can you tell us what you really liked about the book?
Why do you think the book is called so?
Do you know why the first one was titled Sherlock Holmes?
Why does the writer have a collection of stories?
Why is Sherlock Holmes so famous in fiction?

dialogue.sentence:
Adam: I don't understand why meditation is so popular these days.
Jennifer: ----
Adam: Yeah, you're right, all you need is a comfortable posture and wish for self-transformation and desire for others' well-being.
options: It may be because it is derived from various branches of Buddhism.
Because scientists proved that its practitioners are less prone to stress.
I think it's very easy to practise, I mean no equipment and workout is needed.
You know, meditation also leads to some physiological changes in the brain.
Especially three types that developed through Buddhism are very commonly practised.

dialogue.sentence:
Reporter: Studies suggest that we should spend less time in cubicles.
Physician: I agree. Spending time outside boosts our mood and improves our health.
Reporter: ----
Physician: Just simple things like enjoying your drinks or meals outside or doing some workouts outdoors.
options: How can we convince people who don't like outdoor activities?
Do you agree that outdoor activities in big cities are very expensive?
What would you suggest for those who don't know where to start?
Outdoor activities should be preferred when it is warm, shouldn't they?
Is there good evidence that shows the benefits of spending time in nature?

dialogue.sentence:
Fiona: I really admire Roman buildings.
Mary: ----
Fiona: What do you mean?
Mary: Well, it was in ancient Greece that classical architecture emerged and it was the Romans who contributed much to its advancement in terms of complexity.
options: The Romans are known for their contributions to a wide range of subjects from postal services to astronomy.
There are some art historians who claim that the Romans came up with nothing novel to the art of architecture.
The Romans were not the only ones adopting the Greek styles and techniques in their architectural design.
The Roman baths are one of the most distinguished examples of the Roman architectural style.
I guess you should thank both the Greeks and Romans for the elaborate Roman constructions.

dialogue.sentence:
Ann: You read a lot of books, Boris.
Boris: Not really. I've only read two books this month.
Ann: ----
Boris: Why don't you set yourself a goal of one book a month or something?
options: I just don't like reading books. Rather, I'm usually fine with reading my work materials in my spare time.
How do you find enough time to read though you're often busy?
I don't read as much as you. I generally prefer to read best-selling novels.
Two books? That's more than I could bear. I'll stick to magazines.
That's more than I can do. Whenever I start, I always find a good reason to quit.

dialogue.sentence:
Patient: I've been trying to lose weight for a while now.
Dietician: ----
Patient: A couple of times. But nothing actually worked, though I did my best.
options: Well, have you ever consulted a professional before?
How many times do you eat in a typical day?
What kind of diets have you tried until now?
How often do you eat junk food?
How long have you been on this particular diet?

dialogue.sentence:
Interviewer: How did you come up with the idea of drone delivery?
Entrepreneur: Well, I've always had a passion for aviation.
Interviewer: ----
Entrepreneur: One is the capability to operate safely and independently, without crashing into anything or anyone.
options: What do you think you can do to make drone delivery economically more competitive?
Why do you think ordinary people have so many concerns about drone delivery?
How confident are you that people will choose your delivery system?
What are some of the technical improvements you want to achieve to enhance the drone delivery system?
Which types of drones are the most appealing for most customers?

dialogue.sentence:
Sam: The documentary I watched last night claims that animals can predict earthquakes.
May: Even scientists think so.
Sam: Is there any evidence?
May: ----
Sam: Wow! Sounds interesting.
options: There are also many scientists who believe it's impossible to predict natural disasters like earthquakes.
The idea that animals can predict natural disasters isn't actually a new one. 3,000 years ago Chinese scholars were convinced that they could.
I think scientists will have a better understanding of whether animals can in any way feel a natural disaster with more evidence.
Researchers who studied the Etna volcanic eruption and following earthquakes observed that animals reacted during the hours before.
When a natural disaster like a volcanic eruption is underway, the ground under us changes. So, we might be feeling those.

dialogue.sentence:
Tim: I just can't manage to save any money!
Helen: Look, I manage and I don't have a scholarship or a part-time job.
Tim: How do you do it?
Helen: ----
Tim: That's smart! I'll go look for one now.
options: I just stay home watching a movie or playing with my cat.
I find free activities in the student paper. They're really fun!
Well, I don't really like cooking but it's much cheaper. Avoid eating out!
I don't think you should take me as an example. Ask another classmate.
My eldest sister sends me pocket money every school month.

dialogue.sentence:
Justine: There's nothing worth watching at the movies these days.
Kenneth: ----
Justine: It sounds like a science fiction movie rather than a detective one, but seems interesting anyway.
options: I've watched a few extraordinary movies this month, but the one about a detective on a space station was the best.
Last night, I saw a trailer for an interesting detective story where the police used augmented reality to investigate crime scenes.
I know that there's a detective movie that's supposed to have every possible worst-case scenario imaginable in it.
In fact, a science fiction movie is now showing about an intergalactic war.
It makes more sense to watch a pay-per-view detective movie on the Internet.

dialogue.sentence:
Lindy: I've read that travel happiness peaks in the planning stage.
Edith: ----
Lindy: You're right. You have a feeling of contentment when you know that you'll soon do things that entertain you.
options: In fact, it's the same case when you return home.
I think it depends on whether you're able to plan things well.
Really? To be honest, I feel really stressed when I have to think about where to go.
Sure! Even knowing that you're going to see wonderful places, taste delicious foods, or have a good rest can dramatically boost your mood.
Today, travel agencies offer so many alternatives for their customers.

dialogue.sentence:
Interviewer: Tell us about the new environments you've discovered under the sea.
Oceanographer: We've found some very distant environments that harbour life forms.
Interviewer: ----
Oceanographer: We want to find out more about the microbes living beneath the ocean floor.
options: How do you plan to reach such areas beneath the sea?
What do you exactly intend to study in those environments?
What do you know about other creatures living in the sea?
What actually are these life forms in the deep oceans?
Why didn't scientists explore these environments before?

dialogue.sentence:
Mother: I'm looking for a babysitter. Do you have any advice?
Friend: Have you tried asking around?
Mother: Yes, I've invited a girl to meet the children, but I'm not sure what to do next.
Friend: ----
options: You should agree on the fee before she starts.
The most important thing is that your children are happy with her.
If you and the children like her, and you think she seems reliable, you can ask her to come for a trial sit.
It is your responsibility as a parent to satisfy yourself that she is competent.
She should only babysit when she feels well and comfortable.

dialogue.sentence:
Susan: I'm exhausted all the time. I don't know what to do.
Lydia: What time do you go to bed?
Susan: Well, it's quite irregular.
Lydia: Don't play with your circadian rhythm.
Susan: ----
Lydia: It's the body's built-in clock.
options: Where did you learn about circadian rhythm?
For what time should I set my alarm clock to wake up?
I don't. This is already my sleep cycle.
What do you mean by the circadian rhythm?
What's the connection between circadian rhythm and my body clock?

dialogue.sentence:
John: I'm planning to buy an electric car.
Timothy: Some of my friends have already bought some.
John: Are they happy with them?
Timothy: ----
John: I see. Then I should carefully weigh its benefits and downsides.
options: Generally speaking, they are. Just think about how much the technology has improved.
Absolutely. But there are going to be so many new electric models.
Well, yes and no. Most of them bought them for environmental reasons, but some complain about problems with the battery.
Somewhat. They save a lot of money on maintenance.
I don't know, but what I know for sure is that there are more and more charging stations.

dialogue.sentence:
Andy: Were the ancient Egyptians more concerned about death than life?
Jean: On the contrary, they were obsessed with life.
Andy: Then why did they build the Pyramids?
Jean: ----
options: Their tombs contain endless 'daily life' scenes, depicting individuals working in the fields, making wine, dancing and numerous other daily activities.
The ancient Egyptians' attitudes to life and death were heavily influenced by their belief that eternal life could be ensured.
In ancient Egypt, each individual was considered to comprise not only a physical body but also three other crucial elements.
Many recent books have made the point that their real concerns lay somewhere between these two extremes.
Egyptians used to devote most of their time and financial resources to preparations for death.

dialogue.sentence:
Instructor: Did you know that 40% of gold miners in eastern Congo are children?
Student: That's terrible. Children deserve to be in school.
Instructor: ----
Student: I'd promote compulsory education.
options: What would you do to improve their working conditions?
Why do you think Africa lacks basic needs for children's education?
Do you think you can solve this issue by means of international diplomacy?
Don't you agree that this problem requires substantial consideration?
Can you suggest an effective solution to this issue?

dialogue.sentence:
Patient: I've lost my self-confidence lately.
Psychologist: Your problems might be related to your organisation.
Patient: ----
Psychologist: Well, if you want to grow in confidence you need to change your perspective and focus on your strengths.
options: I really don't understand why most of my colleagues burden me with their responsibilities.
I always prioritise my own good when it comes to relations at work.
This is the problem. I always tend to blame myself, not outside factors.
In fact, some organisations arrange seminars to help their employees.
I sometimes watch a movie or go for a walk to forget about my problems.

dialogue.sentence:
Josh: I've read about an MIT study that found lies spread faster than facts on social media.
Christie: ----
Josh: Actually the opposite. The typical person spreading lies tended to have few followers.
options: Do you think the research also explains why so many of us are fooled?
So, Mark Twain was right when he said a lie travels faster than the truth.
Can we say that we shouldn't trust the majority of the stories?
Could it be because lies were being spread by popular social media users?
Did the researchers compare all those stories?

dialogue.sentence:
Frank: I need some help on computer memory.
Sue: Sure. There are two types: RAM and ROM.
Frank: ----
Sue: RAM stores the programs and data you are using in your current work session.
options: So, RAM and ROM are two kinds of memory, then what do the abbreviations stand for?
I need to be able to explain them, so what is the difference between RAM and ROM?
Technically speaking, what are the distinct physical features of these two memory types?
So, can you briefly describe what happens if a memory unit is used at its limits?
What difference does it make if I upgrade one of these units with a newer one?

dialogue.sentence:
Amy: Have you ever heard of Yuncheng Salt Lake?
Pam: Yes! What makes it so beautiful?
Amy: ----
Pam: How's that possible? How can it have such an effect on the lake?
options: The water is brightly coloured due to high temperatures in the region.
In fact, it is the third biggest sodium sulphate lake in the world.
The weather in that region is so hot that tourists hardly come to stay there.
Humans have been harvesting salt in this lake for 4,000 years.
It is in the Shanxi province of northern China – known as the Dead Sea of China.

dialogue.sentence:
Pauline: I always buy too much at the grocery store.
Jill: Empty stomachs are to blame.
Pauline: ----
Jill: Eating some fruit or nuts before heading to the store might help.
options: It's not only the hunger that plays a role, adverts can have a big influence.
The same goes for shopping on the Internet.
For me, it's not the case. There are too many alternatives offered.
I think you're completely right because so much of what's available looks extra-tempting when I'm hungry.
But I often tend to buy cakes and biscuits even when I'm not hungry.

dialogue.sentence:
Louise: My sister doesn't feel healthy these days.
Kate: ----
Louise: So you say factors like high stress and heavy workload might cause her to feel less vigorous.
options: When people get to certain ages, their physical strength may decline.
I think you should observe her behaviours carefully because symptoms like gloomy mood and lack of enthusiasm are associated with depression.
Well, you know health doesn't only mean being free from physical conditions, but it also involves mental and spiritual well-being. You seem to ignore psychological burdens.
Actually, she might be pretending this way so that you can spare enough time for her.
To enjoy good health and boost her energy, she can do regular exercise.

dialogue.sentence:
Daisy: Did you know that keeping a bulb on at night affects your health?
John: Oh, come on. I don't buy it.
Daisy: There is new research on this.
John: ----
Daisy: Well, researchers claim that people who sleep with a light on are more likely to be overweight or have type 2 diabetes.
options: Do you imply that my fear of the dark keeps me from turning the light off?
Don't you think having a light on can make you feel more secure?
Should I always turn the light off and clear my mind?
Do you know any strategies to cope with its side effects?
Do you mean that it's not as innocent as I assume it to be?

dialogue.sentence:
Richard: I watched a documentary about bat communication last night.
Laura: ----
Richard: They claim that the majority of bat interactions are over food.
options: How accurately can they interpret the sounds bats produce?
Most animals produce sounds when they feel threatened, don't they?
That sounds interesting! What's the most striking thing they've found?
Do they use sophisticated devices to identify the sounds bats make?
Does it report that bats also make sounds to entertain themselves?

dialogue.sentence:
Matthew: Why do ants walk in a line?
Russell: They release chemicals called pheromones to communicate.
Matthew: ----
Russell: Exactly! The scents ants give off have many other functions besides helping to identify locations, like signalling the presence of predators.
options: I see. I've also heard that wasps and moths are among the social insects that live in colonies as ants do.
They look highly organised when they're on the march, but it seems they just use their antennae to work as a team.
So you mean they form specific scent trails and follow them to reach food sources or nest sites.
Actually, I know that pheromones have been studied most intensively in insects and mice.
Some ant species follow a straight path while others move in a series of zigzags.

dialogue.sentence:
Journalist: Could you tell us about microscopy in the late 1970s?
Researcher: Back then, we used film-based techniques.
Journalist: ----
Researcher: There is a need to improve our ability to image scales between macro and micro.
options: Can you discuss some of the breakthroughs in the last four decades?
Could you also talk about some of the challenges you are facing now?
Have you ever tried collaborating with other microscopy researchers?
Would you please give examples of the images that earned you prestigious awards?
How do you take such technical photos that are also aesthetically appealing?
